A word of explanation to the person answering this questionnaire

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so don’t worry about leaving blank spaces. Use extra sheets of paper if there is not sufficient space to answer the questions. Don’t hesitate to give details, or describe particular events, if they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Office of the Saskatchewan Archives at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our Province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Saskatchewan.

5. What was your father's name and occupation?
6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and Year).

8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use "I was a small child", "I was in my teens", etc.)

Personally I did not know anything about the west. I suppose my Father got his information about the west by reading about it. And by interviews with men that had been out there.

11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?

Could not say.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)?

Family

13. What means of transportation did you use?

Railway

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement, etc.)

We had no very notable adventure on our way to Montana. In 1881, I remember a trip from Buffalo. We started to be hunting in the railway yards for horses. But when we got to Winnipeg we had to stay there for some time. And when you stepped out of the immigration building ship, you were over your head in mud. So that reminded us how deep and muddy the river was at that time.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

For my brother shortly on the 20-23/13/03.

16. Where did you settle or take up land?

I took up land on the N.W. of 20-29, 13, about 1898.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

And two of my brothers remained almost thirty miles north of Yorkton. From 1893 to 1902, the brothers came in and settled where we cut our hay. And we had to move out in those days then into one 15-30 cents a pound for low weight steers. We kept them till they were three years old. And yet 9½ cents a pound with 8 feet east. Then we would average about $40 on them. While we were doing this work, we had to work on our own land. We had a good deal of work to do.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How, after you came?

I came with my parents and we went ranching. Then went onto my homestead and farmed.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?

We had our own cattle, adventures on our way to Montana in 1881. Remembered stopping at some in Buffalo. We came to the chuckwagon in the railway yards from there. And when we got to Winnipeg, we had to stay there for some time. And when you stepped out of the immigration building ship, you were over your last hope in mind. No matter what happened to have been any sickness, you could only have been in Winnipeg at that time.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

For my brother shortly on the 20-23-13 range.

16. Where did you settle or take up land?

I took up land on the 9th of 20-23-13, about 1898.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

Land near my brothers. Bought about sixty miles north of Yorkton. From 1893 to 1909. The weather was very cold and difficult when we cut over. We had to move back in those days when we were one to two years old. And got 1½ acres a homestead. We bought them still then three years old. And got 1½ acres a homestead. We bought them still then three years old. And got 1½ acres a homestead. We bought them still then three years old. And got 1½ acres a homestead.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How, after you came?

I worked with my parents until we went west. Then went onto any homestead and farmed.

25. When was the first car used in the community? 
   First car purchased by Mr. Johnson in 1923.

26. If you owned a car before 1924, when did you buy it? What make?
   I bought my first car in 1925 from Mr. Smith.

27. Where was your trading center? How far from your home?
   My trading center was located 5 miles away from my home.

28. Did you continue to trade there? (Indicate any changes due to new towns appearing, better means of travel, etc.)
   Yes, I continued to trade there until 1930 when the new town opened up.

29. How often did you shop in the early days?
   Once a month.

30. When (if ever) did people in your district start going to town regularly on Saturdays?
   I started going to town regularly on Saturdays in 1925.

31. When (if ever) did you first begin to buy through the mail order catalogues?
   I began buying through the mail order catalogues in 1926.

32. When did you first have a telephone and what company provided it?
   I got my first telephone in 1928 from the Bell Telephone Company.

33. When you came to Saskatchewan the first time was it with the idea of staying permanently? Or did you make up your mind after trying it out? When did you make this decision?
   I came to Saskatchewan with the idea of staying permanently in 1927.
34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1924? What reasons did they have for moving?

Any one family that I remember, they went Australia.

35. Did many people move away during the 1920s? Did many return?

Why about brother Alexander (W.P.) held office in the council and after that the council held office in the town hall. We moved into the town hall in 1920. My other family came back in 1925. They came back because my father died in 1924. He died in the hospital. He was very sick before he died.

36. If you or some member of your family have held public offices, or have been active in any organizations, mention it here, giving the names wherever possible.

After I served as a trustee on the Board of Education for ten years, I became the President of the Yellow Springs Chamber of Commerce in 1918. I also served as a Trustee on the Board of Education for ten years.

37. If you or any of your family or friends were invited to have or do something in the first automobile, explain where organizing the first district etc., etc.

My father bought his first automobile in 1913. It was a Ford Model T. This was very big news at the time.

38. How did the places in your community get their names (school districts, post offices, villages, railway stations, creeks, hills, etc.)? Try to give: (1) name and meaning of person suggesting place-name; (2) any changes in name since the first name was given; (3) date and reason for change.

The district that I am most familiar with is called Hillside School District. It is still called Hillside School District today. The school district was named after the town of Hillside. There was a pioneer settlement that it still exists today. In 1954, with many decades of history behind it, the school district was dissolved. It was then that the original boundary that was drawn by the town of Hillside was changed. The new boundary included the town of Hillside and the town of New Berlin. The town of Hillside was dissolved in 1960.
34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1914? What reasons did they have for moving?

Only our family that remained in this district.

35. Did many people move away during the war years (1914-1918)?

My schoolmates, classmates, and others who attended my school moved away during this time due to the war.

36. What organizations did your family attend?

After the war, we joined the American Legion and attended local community events.

37. If you or any of your family or friends were uprooted to have or do something in another location, mention the date when you left and why.

My parents moved to Chicago in 1920 because of job opportunities there.

38. How did the places in your community get their names? (School districts, post offices, townships, villages, etc.)

Try to give the first name and meaning of each place name.

(1) School district: Post Office

(2) Townships: Try to give the first name and meaning of each township name.

(3) Villages: Try to give the first name and meaning of each village name.

The district that I attended was named after the post office located in the center of the district.

The township was named after the post office located in the center of the township.

The village was named after the post office located in the center of the village.

39. Give dates of any changes in names of places above.

(1) School district: 1918

(2) Township: 1920

(3) Village: 1925

The school district changed its name in 1918.

The township changed its name in 1920.

The village changed its name in 1925.
